awd_titl_txt: Robust and  Efficient Numerical Methods for Electromagnetic Wave Propagation in Complex Media
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will develop novel mathematical modeling and robust computational methods for simulating wave propagation in complex media such as metamaterials and graphene. This interdisciplinary research has direct applications in nanotechnology and materials through the advancement of discovery and understanding of new phenomena in nanooptics and stealth technology brought by metamaterials and graphene. Graphene can be used to generate picosecond laser pulses because of its wide absorption range, fast decay, and high stability properties. Graphene can be used in sensors to concurrently sense mass, gas, tension, diseases, and explosives; graphene can be used in low-cost display screens of mobile devices, lithium-ion batteries with fast recharge capacity, hydrogen storage for fuel cell-powered cars, and low-cost fuel cells and water desalination, etc. All of these applications benefit from accurate and efficient numerical algorithms for solving the associated mathematical models by reducing the cost of physical experiments. This project will provide support for one PhD student per year. 
 
The focus of this project is to develop and analyze robust and efficient finite element methods for solving electromagnetic wave propagation problems in complex media. Theoretical analysis and practical algorithms will be developed with the following objectives: (1) Further explore some perfectly matched layer (PML) models recently developed for metamaterials, develop and analyze time-domain finite element methods using both edge elements and discontinuous Galerkin methods for solving them; (2) Explore graphene models and efficient FEM algorithms to simulate wave propagation in graphene; (3) Develop robust and efficient a posteriori error estimators for time-dependent Maxwell’s equations in metamaterial and graphene, explore possible superconvergence points for high-order triangular and tetrahedral edge elements; (4) Develop, and analyze efficient numerical methods for Maxwell's equations with random inputs with applications for random metamaterials. The developed algorithms and codes in the project will lead to a better understanding of metamaterials and graphene, and their physical effects, so that researchers can design and use them in applications.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Devloping and analyzing  robust and efficient finite element methods (FEMs) for solving electromagnetic wave propagation problems in complex media plays very important role in many areas of science and engineering, such as material sciences, physics, optics, and bioengineering.

 

During this project, the PI and his collaborators made some significant progress in devloping and analyzing for solving the time-dependent Maxwell's equations in complex media.  More specifically, in the past 4 years, the PI has carried out systematic analysis and simulations of several popular perfectly matched layer (PML) models, such as Ziolkowski’s PML model {results published in 2022 "Journal of Computational Physics", and in 2023 "SIAM Journal on Numerical Analysis");  an equivalent Berenger’s PML model (published in 2023 "ESAIM: Mathematical Modeling and Numerical Analysis"); the Drude metamaterial PML model (published in 2024 "Journal of Computational and Applied Mathematics"). All these works are original, few lmathematical analysis has been done for these PML models. 

In the past 4 years, we also carried out many innovative studies on electromagnetic wave propagation problems, such as

1. developed and studied electromagnetic rotation cloak model (published in 2024 "Journal of Scientific Computing"); 

2. hyperbolic metamaterials with applications for hyperlens (published in 2024 "SIAM Journal on Numerical Analysis"); 

3. electromagnetic concentrator model (published in 2024 "Numerical Methods for Partial Differential Equations");

4. time-domain graphene model with simulations of propagation of surface plasmon polaritons (published in 2023 "Computers & Mathematics with Applications"); 

5. photonic crystal waveguides comprising third-order nonlinear and linear materials (published in 2023 "Journal of Computational and Applied Mathematics");

6. Superconvergence analysis of finite element approximations to Maxwell’s equations in both metamaterials and perfectly matched layers (published in 2024 "Computer & Mathematics with Applications"). 

In summary, our developed algorithms and anlysis of Maxwell's equations in metamaterials and grapene provide scientists and mathemticians better understanding of wave propagation in complex media and their potential applications in electrical engineering, material sciences, optics, physics, nano-technology, and biomedical technology. The support of this project also gave the PI an opportunity to train some young computational mathematicians: The PI graduated one female PhD student in May 2023, and has attracted another US citizen to work with him in 2024,
